For those confused on why last month this video had 3 million dislikes and now it only has half that:

If you're using the show YouTube dislikes extension, then you have to understand that extension doesn't actually know the real number of dislikes, because the dislike data has been removed from YouTube's API. It can only make an estimation, which I assume is done by taking the ratio of dislikes of people using the extension and then using that ratio along with the actual like count to produce the number of dislikes.

For example, if you have 3 real likes, 1 extension like (1 person using the extension, 2 people not) and 1,000,000 extension dislikes, then the calculated number of dislikes is 3,000,000. But if the number of extension likes increases by one to make it 2 extension likes and 1,000,000 extension dislikes, then the calculated number of dislikes is 1,500,000.

I do not believe there is any basis for black Elves. All three initial clans were white, and even if some migrated South (the text only notes them going West and mingling with other Elves), I doubt they survived long given Morgoth's influence. And if some did... I don't see enough time to develop dark pigmentation, given Elves breed slower than Men. And cross-breeding with dark skinned Men would result in Mannish offspring (like Dior) - not Elven.

My take:  1) Arondir is one black elf, with a modern fade haircut, and (so far) no context for why he differs from the other elves.  In the absence of further information, it's immersion-breaking on at least two levels.  2) Look up "Elf" on Wikipedia and scroll down to the etymology section.  Then ask yourself if Tolkien, a philologist, was not aware of that etymology.
Â @LasernatooÂ  "Harfoot breed?"  You haven't read Sir Lenny Henry's description of Harfoots?

Â @MaedhrosÂ  The text also mentions the Nandor (ancestors of the Silvan) migrating south to the mouths of the Anduin, which is separated from Harad by the Bay of Belfalas. They did this during the Years of the Trees, however it remains to be seen whether Amazon will use Tolkien's later idea of the Sun and Moon having existed far earlier (as well as Arda being round from the start) or not. If so, the Nandor could've crossed the bay and potentially had thousands of years to develop darker skin, which certainly seems like enough time, considering the Men in the First Age developed a wide range of skin colors in <500 years.

Â @LasernatooÂ  I was referring to the Nandor. As you said, the furthest known travels isn't really that far. IF they travelled further, and weren't slain or captured, I still don't see pigment working.

Tolkien was reworking timelines specifically to give Men more time to develop. (And again, Elves breed slower... so the generation-evolution would be far harder to happen so quickly).

I think multiple hurders have to be jumped to justify black Elves (which kind of defeats the etymology behind them too).

(Amazon should use the Trees, and not the Sun always existing - we have a promo image of them, albeit dead)

â€¢ No, I definitely don't like the trailer, I think Amazon should definitely make some changes, otherwise this series is going to be a total failure. They could delay the premiere of the series to 2023, and take the project in stride, why? Because I think most Tolkien fans and non-fans aren't going to like it. Today we have the great opportunity to have tools like these, which are comments on YouTube and social networks, if something as simple as that, and Amazon should be attentive to what most people think and although many Sometimes criticism is uncomfortable and even painful, it is always good to take it into account when it is done from a constructive point of view. As a great fan of Tolkien that I am, I would like to leave my humble opinion in the most constructive and respectful way possible, of what I would like to see in the series, because I know that it is not an easy job to interpret Tolkien's work at an audiovisual level and thank Amazon even if I didn't like the series why? For giving me the great opportunity to see one of my dreams come true, I always wondered if in the future there would be the possibility of adapting or finishing the stories that Tolkien left unfinished, whether in books, movies and series, I always wondered if not. there were creative and brilliant contemporary writers or screenwriters, so they will tell us their version of the unfinished stories of middle earth, but at the same time all lovers of their work should participate, through comments and criticism , while it is developing and we all build something spectacular, well without further ado, here is my version of how I think the visual aspect of the series should be and for which audience it should be directed.

This story is set in the second age. From the start of the second age to the start of the third age it's ~3500 years. Then it's another ~3000 years until the events of LotR. My guess, without knowing much about it, is that this tv show is probably set roughly 4000-5000 years before LotR. At the start of the second age Morgoth had just been defeated and Sauron didn't make the rings of power until 1500 years into the age. 

This story could be covering the rise of Sauron following the defeat of Morgoth or it could be something else altogether, but my money's on that it's about Sauron being a sneaky one and tricking everyone. Or it could be a series of leaps through time. They've got elves that have lived all the way through the events to assist as narrative anchors.


Whether they're getting Galadriel right: Well... they've cast an actress who looks a fair bit like Galadriel looked in the movie... Character wise though, Galadriel certainly did become a stately leader before Sauron made the rings but we can't really say she was this all the way through the first and second ages. At the start of the second age she was a banished rebel despite being elven royalty. She was one of the ones who'd much earlier wanted to travel to middle-earth to explore and set up personal kingdoms there away from the elven homelands and she'd refused to return to the elven homelands when invited to.

She didn't even start using the ring of power that she'd been given until the events with Isildur led to the one ring being lost, which is the point that marks the end of the 2nd age. She never used it before then because she didn't trust the one who gave it to her even before it was revealed that he was Sauron. While she was pretty strong in the magical department before, the magically very powerful form you see her in the movies doesn't really come about until after she starts using the ring. Just with that info there we can definitely say she should not be the same in this series as she is in LotR.

I'd say there's plenty of room enough in what Tolkien described about the first to second age for Galadriel to have been a warrior for a spell. They'll get her wrong if they pretend that she's not already spent time as a leader, portray her as battle hungry or not making every effort to avoid wars but the idea of her spending some time as an armed protector and roamer during this era would be well within character scope. As for the ninja stuff, meh, Tolkien's elves were always like that.

Personally I want to see some of the stuff explaining how the elves actually got the worst deal from Eru, who gave the younger races the gift of mortality and a certain freedom that he didn't give to the elves (they have to wait a very long time for this freedom even after they die), or even just a reference to it.

If you're using the show YouTube dislikes extension, then you have to understand that extension doesn't actually know the real number of dislikes, because the dislike data has been removed from YouTube's API. It can only make an estimation, which I assume is done by taking the ratio of dislikes of people using the extension and then using that ratio along with the actual like count to produce the number of dislikes.


For example, if you have 3 real likes, 1 extension like (1 person using the extension, 2 people not) and 1,000,000 extension dislikes, then the calculated number of dislikes is 3,000,000. But if the number of extension likes increases by one to make it 2 extension likes and 1,000,000 extension dislikes, then the calculated number of dislikes is 1,500,000.

There are several reasons why Tolkien fans are not pleased with this.  You can seen Hello Future Me's video, in which he tries to take a balanced approach, but even he explains that most of these reasons are perfectly valid.

Here are a few:
1.  Amazon doesn't actually have the rights to the source material.  They only have rights to about 12 pages of material total.  This means that they're not really telling Tolkien's story, but rather their own using Tolkien's world as a backdrop.

By comparison, take a look at how much material was involved in each of these projects:

LOTR - about 1100 pages.  Three pretty good films.
HOBBIT - about 300 pages.  Three not-so-great films.
RINGS - about 12 pages.  FIVE SEASON TV SERIES.

Do the math; that should tell you the level of quality to expect.

Granted, Amazon could just have created their own fantasy story, and if it was good, we might still like it.  But there are other reasons to think it won't be.

2.  They don't really care about Tolkien's legendarium.  The trailer shows at least a couple of changes they've made to the source material.  For example, why is there a beardless Dwarf?  In Tolkien, female Dwarves have beards.
